elements.title: Match-First Information Hierarchy for Hard-Side Recruitment
elements.problem: The current listing creation flow presents empty forms before showing demand. For hard-side hosts like Dimitri who were recruited by agents with a specific match, this inverts the information hierarchy. Dimitri's motivation is not 'I want to list my apartment' — it's 'I want to see if Ariel and Amber are right for my apartment.' The information architecture must lead with what the host cares about (the match) and follow with what the platform needs (the listing).
elements.solution: Restructure the first-time host experience to lead with the specific match. Scan order: (1) Guest profiles with names, verification status, and interest details, (2) The host's property as the agent described it (pre-filled), (3) What the host needs to do to make this deal happen (minimal steps). This is a demand-led information architecture: show the value first, collect the input second.

evidence.quote: We matched Ariel and Amber as roommates. They both came to us individually looking for a space in the lower Manhattan Midtown area.
evidence.insight: Bryant leads with the match, not the platform. The first-time host page must mirror this: Ariel and Amber's profiles first, listing wizard second.

evidence.quote: Come for the Tool, Stay for the Network.
evidence.insight: The 'tool' is the specific match. The information hierarchy must present the tool before asking the host to invest in the network.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: guest match (who wants your space). Secondary: property details (pre-filled from agent notes). Tertiary: platform mechanics (agreements, payment structure). The host's eyes must land on human faces and names before any form field.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Progressive: Show guest summary first (name, photo, dates, verification badge). Expand to full verification details on tap. Property details shown as a confirmation screen (pre-filled), not a creation wizard.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 information elements on the first screen: guest name/photo, dates they need, verification status. All other details are expandable.

elements.title: Dual-Track Verification Display: Platform Evidence + Personal Access
elements.problem: Dimitri needs two types of verification information simultaneously: (1) what Split Lease has verified (credit check, references, ID), and (2) personal documents he can review himself (driver's license, contact info). Current marketplace patterns show only platform verification badges ('Verified') without exposing the underlying data. For a host who 'usually doesn't deal with third parties,' a badge is insufficient — he needs the evidence.
elements.solution: Create a two-column verification display: Left column shows Split Lease's institutional verification (with methodology). Right column shows the guest's personal documents accessible to the host (with privacy-appropriate redaction). Both columns visible simultaneously, not in separate tabs.

evidence.quote: Still have their information, their driver's license, because you never know.
evidence.insight: Dimitri explicitly requires personal document access. A 'Verified' badge without the underlying document is not enough.

evidence.quote: The hard side of the network is the small percentage of people that typically end up doing most of the work within the community.
evidence.insight: Hard-side users demand more information because they bear more risk. The information architecture must accommodate this asymmetric risk profile.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: verification summary (all checks passed/pending). Secondary: specific check results with evidence (credit score range, reference quotes, ID match). Tertiary: raw documents for host review (redacted as needed).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Layer 1: Badge strip (Verified, Verified, Verified). Layer 2: Expandable rows showing each check with detail. Layer 3: Document viewer for personal review. Host can go as deep as they want without leaving the page.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Badge strip: 3-5 items max. Expanded view: one check at a time. Document viewer: one document at a time with zoom.
scan_order: Specific check the host cares most about (credit/references)
exclude: Legal disclaimers (move to a dedicated section)
Verification methodology details (available on expand, not default)

elements.title: Remote Host Status Architecture: Push-First, Digest-Based
elements.problem: Dimitri will manage his apartment from Europe across timezones. A pull-based information architecture (host logs in to check status) fails for two reasons: (1) timezone differences make real-time checking impractical, and (2) absence of updates is indistinguishable from absence of monitoring. The host needs pushed information that proves the platform is watching even when the host is not.
elements.solution: Design a push-first status architecture: (1) Weekly digest email/notification summarizing everything the host needs to know (rent status, cleaning photos, upcoming guest schedule, issues). (2) Real-time push notifications only for action-required items (lease issue, payment failure). (3) In-app dashboard designed for 10-second timezone-shifted check-ins: status headline first, details below fold. (4) The digest should be a complete snapshot — the host should never need to open the app to understand their property's status.

evidence.quote: I will be in Europe, actually for work.
evidence.insight: 6+ hour timezone difference means the host checks status at off-peak hours. The information must be self-contained in whatever format they check (email, notification, app).

evidence.quote: The Engagement Effect describes the increase in engagement that happens as the network grows.
evidence.insight: For a remote host, the engagement loop is: receive digest -> scan status -> feel reassured -> continue using platform. If the digest stops or becomes uninformative, the loop breaks.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: property status headline ('All good' or 'Action needed'). Secondary: this week's events (rent received, cleaning photos, guest schedule). Tertiary: cumulative metrics (total income, stays completed, ratings).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Email digest: full status in body (no 'click to see more' for critical info). Push notification: one-line status. App dashboard: headline + expandable sections. Each channel must be independently complete.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Weekly digest: scannable in 30 seconds. Maximum 5 status items. If nothing happened that week, the digest says 'Quiet week — everything is on track' with one evidence point (rent confirmed, cleaning photos received).
scan_order: This week's key event (rent, guest arrival, cleaning)
Income summary (if check-in day is near payment)
exclude: Requests for reviews or feedback (separate communication)
Any content not directly related to property status

elements.title: Agreement Translation Architecture: Sublease Terms in Host's Language
elements.problem: Bryant introduces three agreement concepts in 22 seconds: 'custom rental agreement,' 'agreement between yourself and the guests,' and 'supplemental agreement between split lease and the landlord.' Dimitri processes this as a wall of unfamiliar terms overlaid on his known model ('standard sublease agreement'). The information architecture must present these agreements in a structure that maps to the host's existing mental model, not the platform's legal structure.
elements.solution: Present agreements as a visual mapping: 'What you know' (left) -> 'What we add' (right). (1) Start with the host's familiar frame: 'Your standard sublease agreement.' (2) Show what Split Lease adds as a transparent layer: payment guarantee, guest vetting, 24/7 support. (3) The legal documents themselves are presented only after the host understands the conceptual structure. (4) Use visual hierarchy to distinguish between 'your agreement with the guest' (primary, in host's language) and 'Split Lease's guarantee to you' (secondary, as added value).

evidence.quote: Standard sublease agreement... we have a custom rental agreement... supplemental agreement between split lease and us, the landlord.
evidence.insight: Three new concepts introduced in rapid succession. The host's response ('obviously, well, I've never usually dealt directly') shows cognitive overload.

evidence.quote: Making the new product feel familiar, not foreign.
evidence.insight: Agreements should feel like a familiar sublease with extra protection, not a foreign contract with new obligations.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: 'Your sublease, guaranteed by Split Lease' (one-line summary). Secondary: What's the same (standard sublease terms). Tertiary: What's different (payment guarantee, vetting process). The host reads the familiar before the novel.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Summary -> Side-by-side comparison -> Full agreement text. The host can accept after the summary if they trust the agent; they can drill into full text if they want detail.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Summary screen: under 50 words. Comparison view: maximum 5 rows (what's same vs. what's added). Full agreement: standard legal text with section headers that use sublease vocabulary.
scan_order: What stays the same (deposit, monthly rent, rules)
What Split Lease adds (payment guarantee, vetting, support)
exclude: Legal jargon in the summary view
References to 'supplemental agreement' as a primary concept
Fee structure details before the host understands the agreement structure
